why_category_expl: The commit message explains the necessity of changing the license from CPL to EPL due to the fact that CPL is actively hurting JUnit adaptation in certain cases, while EPL would have been fine. This shows that the change is made to meet a specific requirement or problem.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario: when a custom management.port is used and the child context is configured with an EmbeddedServletContainerFactory bean that has the same class as the parent contextâ€™s EmbeddedServletContainerFactory bean, it causes a failure when the custom EmbeddedServletContainerFactory subclass cannot be instantiated. The commit improves the diagnostics to fail fast with an information exception message when this issue is detected.

The commit message describes the issue of a stale view of a bean's type in the BeanTypeRegistry when a bean is overridden and its definition changes. This leads to incorrect bean condition evaluation. The commit message explains why the change is necessary to fix this issue.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by mentioning the issue of dropping a DSS cipher suite. It refers to the issue report of Chrome and Firefox also dropping this cipher suite, which is the reason for the change. This falls under the 'Describe Issue' category.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario: Undertow 1.3.2 changed the default access log file suffix from '.log' to just 'log', which caused a problem in the current implementation. The commit then fixes this issue by adapting the file name pattern to include the missing dot.
The commit message refers to a duplicate console appender in the Actuator sample's logback config, which is an issue scenario that necessitates a code change.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code. It adds more Javadoc to the Assert class for messages and when they are displayed, and it puts the version tag back into the Version class. This shows that the commit was made to enhance the clarity and functionality of the code.

The commit message 'Simplify Filter implementation for backward compatibility' suggests that the change was made to address an issue with the previous implementation. Specifically, the change removes the need for a separate method to filter out ignored tests, which simplifies the code and ensures backward compatibility.

The commit message refers to an 'important Android fix' in RxJava 1.0.14. This indicates that there was a known issue in the previous version that has been addressed in the new version. Therefore, the commit is made to resolve this issue, which falls under the 'Describe Issue' category.

The commit message mentions 'Format code', which implies that the code change is being made to improve readability and maintainability. The diff shows changes to variable declarations, adding 'final' modifiers to make them immutable and 'static' to make them class-level constants. This can be seen as fixing an issue with the previous implementation, as it improves code quality and adheres to best practices.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario. It mentions that the change is required to handle a specific Android scenario where an older version of OkHttp bundled with an application might pick up the newer HttpResponseCache via ResponseCache.getDefault(). This could lead to an UnsupportedOperationException being thrown. The commit message explains that the previous fix to HttpResponseCache re-introduced get()/put() but didn't implement the necessary instanceof checks, which caused the issue. The message also mentions that the change is necessary to maintain compatibility with other implementations of HttpURLConnection and to follow the letter of the Java API.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code by renaming a method and adding a new API. This change is made to better align the terminology used with the conventions of cryptography.

The commit message describes the issue of duplicate resources in the classpath, which can cause logback to worry about double configuration. The code diff also supports this by removing the duplicate resources from the target directory.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue with the previous implementation. It mentions that 'preferred-mapper' property is being renamed to 'preferred-json-mapper' to make it clear that it only affects the JSON mapper and not the XML mapper. This is done to address the confusion caused by the previous name of the property.

The commit message refers to the need to discourage the use of Java 8 due to the built-in support for CompletableFuture and Optional in Retrofit. This is a change made to meet the requirements of the software development process, specifically to update the codebase to work with newer versions of Java.

The commit message refers to an issue (the new role-based method) that necessitates an update to the documentation. This falls under the 'Describe Issue' category as it directly elaborates the motivation for the code change.

The commit message explains the reason for the change, which is the transition from CVS to Git. This is a significant change in the development environment, which is the source of the requirement mentioned in this category.

The commit message refers to the unnecessary logging by the start-docker script, which is an issue that needs to be addressed. The code diff shows that the logging behavior is being changed, which is a direct code change motivated by the issue of unnecessary logging.

The commit message explicitly mentions the issue of the cache not working properly when a service/reference is registered more than one time without an explicit id. This directly elaborates the motivation of the code change, which is to fix a specific problem or error scenario.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario: 'Bug: ParentRunner lost test Class from a separate class loader'. This issue is explained in detail, including the error scenario and the problem it causes.

The commit message explains the requirement of software development for the need to connect to TLSv1.0 or TLSv1.1 servers due to the deprecation of these versions by some browsers. This is a necessary change to stay secure and up-to-date with the evolving TLS ecosystem.

The commit message refers to the issue of updating RxJava from version 1.0.0-rc.4 to version 1.0.0. This could be due to a bug or a shortcoming in the previous version, which the commit message does not elaborate on. Therefore, the most suitable category is 'Describe Issue'.

The commit message describes the issue of the current implementation throwing unchecked exceptions on unexpected charsets, which can cause a misbehaving webserver to crash the client. The commit aims to change this failure mode to not crash on charset problems.

The commit message refers to the issue of incompatibility with JDK 15 due to the introduction of isEmpty() on CharSequence. This is a clear description of the problem scenario, making it necessary to change the code.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the bug it fixes. The bug is that when using DiskLruCache, the hasNext() method of Iterator<Snapshot> returned by snapshot() method can iterate through lruEntries, and if an entry is not completed yet, it is removed, causing the file not to be cached at all. The commit message provides a clear explanation of this issue and how it was fixed.
Error: 400 - {"object":"error","message":"Prompt contains 51476 tokens, too large for model with 32768 maximum context length","type":"invalid_request_error","param":null,"code":null}

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario: a NullPointerException (NPE) in Maven when a settings.xml file contains a file-activated profile. This issue was made worse by the NPE not being included in the resulting failure message, which hampered diagnosis of the problem. The commit fixes this issue by updating MavenSettings to configure its FileProfileActivator with a PathTransformer and improving the failure message to include a problem's exception if it has one.

The commit message describes the issue of users being confused when they follow the logback documentation and specify the `logback.configurationFile` system property. The code change is made to address this issue by logging a warning when this specific property is found.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario. It mentions that when '@ConditionalOnBean' or '@ConditionalOnMissingBean' are used on a '@bean' method, they may fail to deduce the bean's type. The commit message provides examples of possible failure causes and explains that previously, this failure was only logged as a debug message, leaving the user with a misleading message. The commit improves the diagnostics by mentioning the possibility of type deduction in the exception message and including the exception that caused deduction to fail as the cause. This makes it clearer to the user what went wrong.

The commit message 'Remove redundant field fCause' indicates that the field 'fCause' is no longer needed because it is replaced by the 'initCause' method. This change is likely made to eliminate redundancy and simplify the code, which can be considered as an issue or shortcoming in the previous implementation.

The commit message explains that the change is necessary due to a problem in the software development environment. Specifically, it mentions that Maven 3.1.1 uses HTTP instead of HTTPS for resolving artifacts from Maven Central, and Maven Central recently discontinued HTTP support. This caused the build on Travis to start failing. The commit then describes the solution, which is to use an HTTPS mirror of Maven Central.

The commit message 'update version to 2.1.6' directly mentions the change made to the code, which is updating the version of the project from 2.2.0-SNAPSHOT to 2.1.6. This could be due to the release of a new stable version or for other reasons. However, the reason for the update is not explicitly stated in the commit message.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue - the HttpURLConnection CloseGuard warning due to the lack of close on GZIPInputStream. This issue is also referenced in the original AOSP/libcore commit and the bug report number.

The commit message refers to an issue (the incorrect link to the 4.12 release notes) and directly elaborates the motivation of the code change. The message describes the problem (the incorrect link) and the solution (the correct link).

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario - the character encoding filter not setting the request's encoding before other filters attempt to read the request. This is a clear explanation of why the commit updates the order of OrderedCharacterEncodingFilter to be HIGHEST_PRECEDENCE.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the problem with boolean vals and SAM types in Kotlin callsites. This is a clear indication of the necessity of the changes to fix existing source patterns.

The commit message refers to the issue of MockSpdyPeer interfering with Android tests, causing the current test to fail due to an UncaughtExceptionHandler. The change in the code diff is made to prevent this exception from propagating out of the call stack, which is directly addressing the mentioned issue.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue with the testStatusChecker, stating that it is unstable and suggesting removal in the future. The diff also shows the use of the @Ignore annotation to temporarily disable the test.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue it fixes: a race condition in Connection.isExpired() that was causing some SPDY connections to be evicted early and preventing connection reuse. This issue is explained in detail, including its impact on the system and the tests that were affected.

Error: 429 - {"message":"API rate limit exceeded"}

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario: it was incorrect to simply replace existing instances because you can't tell from the instance which media types and java types it supports. This fix just prepends the custom converters so they get higher priority.

The commit message describes an issue with the current implementation where the `@QueryMap` annotation with `encoded=true` is causing incorrect URL encoding. This is a problematic scenario that necessitates a code change to fix the issue.

The commit message describes the issue of missing tests for RxJava Single type support and the need to add more tests to cover Single.toBlocking() which is present since RxJava 1.0.16 version. This indicates that the change is necessary to improve the codebase and ensure its robustness.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the error scenario that occurred when trying to bind the property from the environment. The error was caused by the nested private static class, which was not accessible. The solution to the issue is to change the nested class from private to public.

The commit message describes the issue of the provider token check failing silently, making it difficult for the consumer to locate the failure. The code change addresses this issue by printing out the token value in the exception information.

The commit message describes the issue of the previous implementation always sending a frame for every FrameSink#write and an empty frame for FrameSink#close. The new implementation only emits bytes once Okio reports complete segments, which is a more efficient solution.

The commit message mentions the need to migrate from Travis to GitHub Action for publishing. This is likely due to a requirement or problem in the process of software maintenance, such as the need for a more modern and efficient continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) system.

The commit message refers to the issue of better matching under JavaNetCookieJar by injecting a leading dot in the domain pattern. This is necessary to make 'example.com' match 'www.example.com' under RFC 2965, which is an issue that the commit message directly elaborates on.

The commit message mentions that it 'brought in old JUnit4ClassRunner for compatibility' and 'renamed new JUnit4ClassRunner to BlockJUnit4ClassRunner'. This suggests that the change was made to ensure compatibility with older versions of JUnit or to introduce new functionality, which is a clear objective of the code change.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code. It adds new methods (getTag() and logChunk()) to the AndroidLog class to make it easier for subclassing. This is done to improve the flexibility and extensibility of the class.

The commit message refers to the issue of javadoc errors that are currently causing the build to fail. The change in the script is made to temporarily ignore these errors during the deployment process, which is a direct elaboration of the motivation for the code change.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by referring to an issue link and a pull request link. The code diff adds a defensive check to handle a potential null pointer exception, which could be a scenario described in the issue.

The commit message explicitly mentions a bug in the release plugin (http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MRELEASE-812) that the code change is addressing. This falls under the 'Describe Issue' category as it directly elaborates the motivation of the code change.

The commit message refers to the issue of tests not showing the stack trace of the test thread when they timeout. This is a clear description of a problem scenario, which is the motivation for the code change.
The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue it fixes, which is Android bug 41739, and the need to support HTTP 307 temporary redirects.

The commit message describes the objective of the changes, which is to introduce a new component called Exchange. This component is part of a larger refactoring effort that aims to split StreamAllocation into three parts: ExchangeFinder, Exchange, and Transmitter. The Exchange component represents a single request/response pair, and the commit message indicates that this is the last big refactoring step.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of a code change by describing the issue of flakiness in the CallTest.cancelTagImmediatelyAfterEnqueue() method. The issue is that there's a race where the HTTP engine has been created, but not yet connected, and the cancel isn't as immediate as it could be. The commit message explains that the test is being fixed by making sure there's a response to be retrieved, which addresses the described issue.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario with Log4J2's shutdown hook causing a race condition during application context closure, which results in lost logging. This issue is clearly explained in the message, making it a suitable fit for the 'Describe Issue' category.

The commit message refers to the need to update the documentation due to changes in the codebase. Specifically, it mentions the handling of '@field' and '@part' values, which have been modified in the diff. This implies that there was an issue or shortcoming in the previous documentation that needed to be addressed.
The commit message refers to a specific issue (doclint issues causing the site goal to fail) and describes the motivation for the code change (to disable parts of doclint for the site's javadoc).

The commit message refers to an obsolete annotation (@JvmField) that is no longer needed because the Java file (Dispatcher.java) it was used in has been converted to Kotlin. This change is made to address the issue of having unnecessary code in the codebase.
The commit message refers to a change in the required Java version due to a change in a prior commit. This is done to meet the software development requirements, illustrating the need for the change.

The commit message refers to the removal of the old SSL protocol method, which is likely due to the deprecation of the method in newer versions of the library. This change is made to address the issue of using an outdated SSL protocol, which could pose security risks.
The commit message explicitly mentions that the maven-eclipse-plugin has been retired, which is an issue that necessitates the removal of the plugin from the project.

The commit message explicitly mentions that the 'okhttp-protocols' module no longer exists, which is the issue that necessitates the removal of the 'fat' jar creation. The code diff also supports this by removing the configuration for the 'maven-assembly-plugin' which was used to create the 'fat' jar.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue with the previous implementation - the redundant nested filters created when applying a filter to a nested suite. This falls under the 'Describe Issue' category.
The commit message refers to the issue of having to jarjar the GSON library. Since the library is being jarjared, it needs to be marked as provided to avoid classpath conflicts during runtime.

The commit message refers to a dead link in the documentation, which is an issue that needs to be fixed. The link has been moved to a new location, and the commit message explains this change, providing the new correct link.

The commit message describes the objective of the change, which is to move the code out of the libcore package to promote it into AOSP. This is done to keep the package as-is and do the jarjar in Android instead. This change improves the code structure and organization.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario with REFUSED_STREAM errors, which are causing large numbers of connections to be created. The commit message also mentions that the ExchangeFinder interface is still inadequate to support all of the use cases, indicating a shortcoming of the previous implementation.

The commit message mentions modifying comments and imports, which suggests that the changes are being made to improve the readability and maintainability of the code. The diff shows that the changes are made to improve the logging messages, which could be done to clarify the purpose of the code and to make it easier to understand the flow of the program. This could be considered as describing an issue, i.e., the need for clearer and more descriptive logging messages to improve the maintainability of the code.

The commit message refers to the deprecated error identifier in the code, which is causing tech debt. The message mentions that the whole class might die or morph in the future, implying that the deprecated error identifier is an issue that needs to be addressed. The commit is made to remove the deprecated error identifier to clean up the code and reduce tech debt before major refactorings.

The commit message refers to the need for software maintenance and the removal of deprecated properties to support additional strategies and to make the codebase more up-to-date. This is a common requirement in software development to ensure the codebase remains functional, secure, and efficient.

The commit message explains the motivation for the code change by mentioning that the IDE plugin supports both the `/.eclipse` and `/eclipse` directories. This implies that the previous location of the `eclipse.properties` file was causing an issue, and moving it to the `/eclipse` directory resolves that issue.

The commit message explains the requirement for the change by stating that OkHttp 3.14.x is no longer supported and that OkHttp 4.x is the only branch receiving security fixes, bug fixes, and new features. This implies that the change is necessary to ensure the security and functionality of the software.

The commit message refers to the issue of outdated ProGuard configurations. It mentions that as of API 26, the android.jar contains the classes checked by Platform and used by Platform.Java8. This means that the previous ProGuard configurations are no longer necessary and need to be removed. Additionally, the message mentions that throwing checked exceptions from the service method is not encouraged, which further justifies the removal of the ProGuard configurations.

The commit message explains the issue that is being addressed, which is the Android-specific implementation detail of chunking that is now only performed when needed. This implies that the previous implementation was not optimal and needed to be changed.

The commit message explains the issue that the code change is addressing: the current implementation of the forced suspension mechanism can lead to UndeclaredThrowableExceptions being seen in certain scenarios. The message describes the error scenario and the motivation for the change.

The commit message 'Fix broken links in the documentation' directly elaborates the motivation of the code change. It describes the issue scenario, which is the presence of broken links in the documentation.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario - the previous implementation of the `PersistenceExceptionTranslationPostProcessor` was always configured to use cglib, regardless of the value of the `spring.aop.proxy-target-class` property. This commit fixes that issue by honouring the `spring.aop.proxy-target-class` property if set by the user.

The commit message explains the issue of logging the classpath too early in the application startup process, which could lead to logging being disabled or not having the correct log levels applied. The commit moves the logging to happen later in the application startup process to ensure that the logging system has been initialized and its levels have been configured.

The commit message directly mentions the improvement it makes to the code by allowing service interfaces to extend other interfaces. This is done because a higher minSdkVersion no longer prevents this on Android.

The commit message explains the reason for the change by mentioning that Mockito needs version 1.6 and Hibernate pulls in version 1.5 of byte-buddy. This indicates that the change is necessary to meet the requirements of the dependencies used in the project.
The commit message refers to a typo in the README.md file, which is an issue that needs to be fixed. The code diff also shows the correction of the typo in the comment of the build.gradle file.

The commit message directly mentions the improvement it makes to the code: 'Pull out ServiceMethod base class' to allow support for multiple forms of invocation beyond HTTP calls. This change is made to enhance the functionality of the code.

The commit message describes the need for the change, which is to provide multiple build profiles that make it possible to easily try out different session stores. This is done to accommodate the requirement of software development for different session store types.

The commit message refers to a specific issue where the h2-console requires a servlet-based web application. This directly elaborates the motivation of the code change, describing the error scenario and the need for the change.

The commit message refers to a typo in the documentation, which is an issue that needs to be fixed. The diff shows the exact change made to correct the typo, further emphasizing the necessity of the change.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue it addresses. The issue is that the method FrameworkMethod.getParameterSignatures() from the 'core' of JUnit depends on something from 'experimental'. This dependency is going in the wrong direction, which is the motivation for removing the method.
The commit message refers to an issue with the formal release of the spring-context-support dependency, which is broken. This directly elaborates the motivation of the code change.

The commit message explicitly mentions the need to change the version to prepare for the next major release. This is a clear indication of a requirement or problem in the process of software maintenance, which falls under the 'Ilustrate Requirement' category.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue: the application thread wants to be active, writing to its OutputStream, but in OkHttp's API, this work wants to happen in the RequestBody.writeTo() callback. To make this work, the commit introduces a Pipe class that allows the HttpUrlConnection OutputStream to be the sink end of the pipe, and the RequestBody the source end of the pipe. This is done to address the issue of backpressure, timeouts, and failures not propagating as expected.

The commit message refers to a specific issue (pr#4339) and the code diff shows the removal of unnecessary spaces. This is likely a formatting change to improve readability and maintainability of the code, which can be considered an issue to address.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements made to the code, such as moving the connection pooling logic and specifying what to do when the connection becomes idle: pool, close, or hold. This indicates that the change was made to improve the functionality or efficiency of the code.

The commit message only mentions fixing a spelling error, but it does not provide a reason or rationale for the change. In this case, it is a simple typographic fix, which often falls under the 'Missing Why' category.

The commit message refers to the issue of the outdated key `spring.metrics.export.redis.aggregate-key-pattern` that was still referenced in the documentation but is no longer defined. This clearly describes the motivation for the code change, which is to fix an error scenario or a shortcoming in the previous implementation.

The commit message explicitly mentions 'Fix export provider error', which indicates that there was a problem in the previous implementation that the commit is addressing. The changes made in the code diff, such as changing the log level from info to error and catching Throwable instead of ClassNotFoundException, are likely to resolve the issue.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by mentioning the issue of duplicate dependency in the [dubbo-bom] and [dubbo-demo-xml-consumer]. The diff also supports this by removing the duplicate dependency from the pom.xml files.

The commit message explains the reason for the change as it mentions that most apps that use Spring Batch will prefer to use a RDBMS of their choice to store batch metadata. This is a requirement that the change is addressing.

The commit message 'Prepare next development version' describes the improvements it makes to the code, such as adding new features (e.g., built-in support for Kotlin's `Unit` type, Java 8's `Optional` and `CompletableFuture` types), fixing bugs (e.g., preventing the RxJava type from being disposed by `onSubscribe`), and updating dependencies (e.g., OkHttp dependency to 3.12).

The commit message directly mentions the defects it fixes, which are inconsistencies in javadocs. Specifically, it mentions changing self-closing

tags to regular

tags and adding missing

tags. This indicates that the commit is aimed at improving the code by fixing these issues to make the javadocs more consistent and properly formatted.

The commit message refers to the need for a refactor of the package, which could be due to outdated code or changes in the development environment. This implies that there is a requirement for the code to be updated or improved.
Error: 400 - {"object":"error","message":"Prompt contains 71474 tokens, too large for model with 32768 maximum context length","type":"invalid_request_error","param":null,"code":null}

The commit message 'javadoc'ed, and with better names' indicates that the changes made to the code are to improve the documentation and naming conventions. This is a clear explanation of the improvements made to the code, which falls under the 'Describe Objective' category.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue that the previous samples are no longer relevant due to the change in default versions of Tomcat and Jetty. The commit is necessary to ensure compatibility with older versions of Tomcat and Jetty.
Invalid control character at: line 1 column 4 (char 3)

The commit message refers to the issue of not being able to auto-detect default values for Enums and Collections, which is a shortcoming of the previous implementation. The commit is fixing this issue by providing manual metadata to document default values for properties in the class.

The commit message explains that the use of a property to define the hamcrest version can cause issues for others, especially when multiple dependencies need to be kept in sync. In this case, since there is only one dependency and it doesn't need to be synced with any other dependency, the commit message describes the issue (potential issues with using properties for dependency versions) and the solution (directly specifying the version in the dependency).

The commit message 'Added some names to list of contributors' indicates that the change was made to meet a requirement. In this case, the requirement is to keep the list of contributors up-to-date. This is a common need in software maintenance, where keeping documentation and credits accurate is important.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code by switching to a 'better, custom validating subscriber' that ensures all events are tested and consumes events as they're validated. This change is made to improve correctness testing and make assertion more like a script than a ledger.

The commit message describes the issue of fatal errors not crashing the dispatcher thread and non-fatal exceptions reaching OkHttpCall not logging properly. It also mentions a fix for the RxJava 2 async adapter where non-200 responses delivered to the body observer would be forwarded to onError, and if that callback threw a fatal exception, it would be re-delivered to the body observer despite it having already called a downstream terminal method. The fatal error should have been propagated by the async observer instead.

The commit message refers to the need to fix typos in the documentation, which is a clear issue that needs to be addressed. The diff shows the specific changes made to correct the typos, further supporting the necessity of the commit.

The commit message directly mentions the change it makes to the code, which is making the OkHttpClient accessors final. This is done to ensure compatibility with Kotlin, as open accessors cannot be represented as vals in Kotlin. The motivation for this change is also explained in the message, stating that the motivation to make these non-final was weak and the decision was made to break API compatibility here.

The commit message explains the requirement for the change, which is the need to apply the configuration to all JDKs, not just pre-12. This is because Error-prone only works on JDK 11 or older currently, and the configuration is moved out of the error-prone block to apply to all JDKs.

The commit message refers to the need to update the build_tests.sh script to test 'ant profile' due to the errors mentioned in the diff. These errors are likely the result of an issue or shortcoming in the previous implementation, which the commit aims to address.

The commit message 'Read/write access for byte, short and int' directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code, which is adding read/write access for byte, short, and int data types. This is a clear indication of the objective of the commit.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code by defining async APIs and switching Job to use HttpEngine directly. This change introduces some duplicated code with HttpURLConnection and breaks the response cache, but it is considered the best route going forward.

The commit message 'Polish RSocket support' directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code. The changes in the code diff are mostly about adding 'final' modifiers to variables and methods, which is a common practice to improve code quality and readability.

The commit message refers to warnings found by errorprone, which is a tool that helps catch common mistakes as compile-time errors. The warnings are about unnecessary use of grouping parentheses. By removing these parentheses, the code becomes cleaner and easier to read, which is a valid reason for a code change.

The commit message explains the issue it is addressing: if an Endpoint is already annotated with @ManagedResource, it doesn't need an additional MBean registration based on the invoke() method. This is a clear description of the problem and the reason for the change.

The commit message 'Make ParallelComputer more beautiful by creating a Decorator extension point in ParentRunner' directly mentions the improvement it makes to the code, which is the addition of a Decorator extension point in the ParentRunner class to make the ParallelComputer more beautiful, i.e., to enhance its functionality.

The commit message refers to the unnecessary null check that is removed in the diff. This change is likely made to simplify the code and improve its readability. The issue described is the presence of the null check, which is no longer necessary after the change.

The commit message 'Remove unnecessary dependencies' directly elaborates the motivation of the code change. The removed dependencies are no longer needed in the project, which can be considered as a shortcoming of the previous implementation.

The commit message refers to the removal of an unnecessary null check in the code. This could be considered an issue because the null check was not necessary and could potentially lead to unnecessary computations or checks. The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code. It adds details to the Jest Elasticsearch HealthIndicator to align it with the changes made for the REST variant. This includes parsing the JSON response differently and adding more details to the health check.

The commit message explicitly mentions the improvements it makes to the code by adding an example of using JSON converter as a String converter and modifying the stringConverter method to accept a Retrofit instance as a parameter. This change brings the method signature into parity with the other converter methods, making the code more consistent and functional.
The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by mentioning the deprecation of junit.framework.Assert and the use of static import for better readability.

The commit message refers to 'Issue 551: Resolve sensitive equality in MethodSorter test', which is a specific problem that the code change is addressing. The diff shows that the indentation in the method getDeclaredFilteredMethods has been cleaned up, which could be a result of the refactoring conducted by Eclipse that was mentioned in the commit message. This suggests that the change is being made to resolve the issue described in Issue 551.

The commit message explains that the change is made to improve the platform-specific line separator usage in the code. This is done to ensure that the code behaves consistently across different platforms, which is a common issue that can lead to problems in software maintenance.

The commit message explains the issue of users potentially forgetting to include the `spring-context-support` dependency when using `spring-boot-starter-cache`. This is clarified in the commit message to make it more obvious that the starter includes this additional dependency.

The commit message refers to the need to add missing Call wrappers as return type. This is likely due to the issue that the previous implementation did not wrap the return type with Call, which could have caused runtime errors or unexpected behavior. Therefore, the category is 'Describe Issue'.

The commit message explicitly mentions the issue of 'Fix isClosed() when a cache has not been initialized' and how it was previously interpreted differently. This clearly falls under the 'Describe Issue' category.

The commit message 'Add missing import' directly elaborates the motivation of the code change. It is describing the issue scenario, which is the missing import statement in the code. This is necessary to fix a compilation error that would have occurred without the import.

The commit message explains the motivation for the code change by mentioning that the method Assert.assertThrows provides a nicer way for verifying exceptions and that the use of ExpectedException is error-prone when used with other rules like TestWatcher because the order of rules is important in that case. This directly elaborates the issue with the previous implementation and describes the motivation for the change.
The commit message refers to a bug in resumed TLS sessions where the wrong protocol could be selected. This is a clear description of the issue that necessitates the code change.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code by exposing the success type on RetrofitError. This change is made to fully test all the variants of successful and erroneous handling of sync, async, and rx.

The commit message 'Add missing copyright headers' indicates that the change is made to comply with the Apache License, Version 2.0. This is a requirement for using the file, as stated in the license itself. Therefore, this commit falls under the 'Illustrate Requirement' category.

The commit message explicitly mentions that the test was asserting a header generated using a copy of the old broken implementation. This directly elaborates the motivation of the code change, which is to fix the issue in the test.

The commit message 'Add missing dependency' refers to the need for the 'spring-test' dependency in the project. This is likely due to the addition or modification of tests in the codebase, which requires the 'spring-test' dependency. Therefore, the category 'Ilustrate Requirement' is the most suitable.

The commit message describes the need to modify the environment, which is a requirement for the software. It introduces a new extension point, EnvironmentPostProcessor, that allows classes to modify the environment. This is done to accommodate the need for software development and maintenance, specifically to handle changes in the runtime or development environment.

The commit message refers to the need to make the code cleaner, which could imply that there is an issue with the current implementation. The diff shows that the code is being refactored to improve readability and maintainability, which is a common motivation for code changes.

The commit message explains that the now-useless HttpServiceMethod.Builder is being removed because a simple static factory will do. This implies that the Builder class was complex and unnecessary, and the commit message describes the issue of unnecessary complexity.

The commit message mentions the need to add a new 'staticondemandthreshold' setting to the Eclipse project jdt.ui preference settings file. This is done to address the need for additional configuration options, which can be considered a requirement for the software development.

The commit message 'Fixup version numbers following release' directly mentions the improvement it makes to the code, which is updating the version numbers. This is likely due to a new release, and the change is necessary to reflect the updated version.

The commit message refers to the removal of unused variable parameters in the AbstractProxyInvoker. This is done to fix an issue where the code was unnecessarily accepting and processing parameters that were not being used. This can lead to unnecessary overhead and potential bugs.

The commit message 'Pom version updates. Drop unused dependencies.' indicates that the changes are being made to update the versions of certain dependencies and remove those that are no longer in use. This is likely due to a requirement for keeping the software up-to-date and maintaining a clean and efficient project structure.

The commit message refers to Issue 551, which is about resolving sensitive equality in the MethodSorter test. The code change uses assertArrayEquals instead of converting an array to a list to avoid this sensitivity. This directly elaborates the motivation of the code change, which is to fix the issue reported in Issue 551.

The commit message mentions the need to update the URL connection client for Android 2.2 and prior and when on the JVM. This is done to accommodate the deprecation of the Twitter API and the need to use GitHub contributors instead. This change is made to meet the requirements of the software development process and to address a problem in the process of software maintenance.

The commit message mentions the need to drop JDK 8 support and cleanup repo locations to use spring.io. This is likely due to a requirement or problem in the software maintenance process, such as outdated code or a change in the development environment.

The commit message explicitly mentions the issue of the previous implementation mapping the connection idle timeout and heartbeat interval to seconds when Cassandra expects milliseconds. This directly elaborates the motivation for the code change.

The commit message directly mentions the objective of the code change, which is to move cache writing out of the transport. This is done to unblock network interceptors, where the interceptor may elect to rewrite the response body. If we've already cached the original response body, we're too late. This change is made to fix the issue of not being able to rewrite the response body after it has been cached.

The commit message refers to a typo in the code, which is a common issue that needs to be fixed. The typo 'Assert4J' is incorrect and should be 'AssertJ', as indicated in the diff. This change is necessary to ensure the correct functioning of the code.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code by using ServerError directly in sessionExpired and serverError. This change is made to support HTTP body format agnostic, which is a clear objective.

The commit message refers to the issue of having a misleading exception variable name 'e' in the 'catch' block, which is not being used. The proper name 'ignored' is more descriptive and accurate, indicating that the exception is intentionally ignored.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code, which is the addition of HTTP/2 automatic pings and the separation of listener executors from writer executors. This change is made to improve the functionality and reliability of the HTTP/2 connection.

The commit message refers to the issue of inconsistent indentation in the YAML example, which is causing a problem. The commit replaces tabs with spaces to fix this issue, improving the readability and correctness of the documentation.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue scenario: when MVC path matchers are used as metric keys, they can still contain invalid characters and patterns. This change removes some more special characters and tidies up the names to avoid keys starting or ending with '-', which is considered ugly.

The commit message refers to the issue of missing HTTP/2 and TLSv1.3 support in some security providers. This is directly elaborating the motivation of the code change, which is to address the shortcoming of the previous implementation.

The commit message explains that the 'javadoc/latest' folder has been missing for a while, which has caused issues with the availability of Javadoc pages. The message also mentions that there are links to Javadoc at that folder, and restoring the folder will hopefully restore the Javadoc pages in Google Search as well.

The commit message refers to the issue of updating the link to Mockito in the README.md file. The old link was pointing to Google Code, which is now deprecated, and the new link points to the GitHub repository. This change is necessary to ensure that the documentation remains accurate and up-to-date.

The commit message refers to the issue of competition during the shutdown logic of spring bean destroy. This issue is being addressed by removing the shutdown logic from spring bean destroy to avoid competition.

The commit message mentions the need for uploading documentation, which is a requirement for software maintenance. The diff shows the addition of a script for uploading docs and the corresponding scp command, which is used for transferring files over a network. This implies that the documentation needs to be made available to users or other stakeholders, which is a requirement.
The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the bug it fixes: the method parameters and constructor parameters were switched in Theories classes.
The commit message refers to the issue of tests not being able to be run in parallel due to the use of static fields in the tests. This directly elaborates the motivation for the code change.

The commit message 'Rename main class to Retrofit' indicates a change in the codebase, specifically renaming a class. This is done to improve the code, likely to better reflect the library's functionality or to align with naming conventions. Therefore, the commit message falls under the 'Describe Objective' category.

The commit message explains the motivation for the code change by describing the issue with the current implementation. The issue is that the 'assertThat' method is used from JUnit's Assert class, but it is recommended to use Hamcrest's own 'assertThat' method directly. This is because Hamcrest is an independent assertion library and contains its own 'assertThat' method, which is available in both the old and current versions of Hamcrest. By deprecating JUnit's 'assertThat' method, the code is made more consistent and in line with the recommendations of the Hamcrest team.

The commit message 'Fix typo <issue_link>' indicates that the change was made to correct a typographical error. The diff shows that the variable 'prifix' was misspelled as 'priefix'. This falls under the 'Describe Issue' category as it directly elaborates the motivation of the code change, which is to fix an error in the code.

The commit message directly mentions the objective of the code change, which is to 'Register an AuthenticationManager in security autoconfig'. This is done to make it easier to reason about what Spring Boot has done for you and to default in simple use cases to the boot-created AuthenticationManager.

The commit message refers to a convention regarding the location of tests, which is to add tests to the same package as the class under test. This is not explicitly stated in the message, but it is implied by the action of moving the test class to a different package.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by describing the issue that is being fixed. The issue is that the code is trying to access `MethodHandles.Lookup` on Android API 24 and 25, which is not available on those versions. The fix is to prevent this access on those specific Android API versions.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code by creating a new class 'TestWithParameters' and modifying existing classes to use this new class. This change is made to make it clear that the computation of the name is not the responsibility of the runner but of the Parameterized class.

The commit message directly mentions the improvement it makes to the code: 'New Suite implementation makes ClassesRequest crazy simple'. This implies that the change was made to simplify the ClassesRequest class, which can be inferred to have been made more efficient or easier to use.

The commit message only mentions the changes made to the README.md file without providing a rationale for these changes. Since the changes are typographical and grammatical fixes, it is easy to infer the necessity of these changes without explicitly stating it in the commit message.

The commit message mentions the need to upgrade the tomcat version to 8.5.31 due to a requirement. This is indicated by the phrase 'Upgrade tomcat version to 8.5.31'. The code diff also supports this by changing the version number in the pom.xml file.

The commit message 'keep demo simple, and switch to use zookeeper as registry center' indicates that the change is being made to meet a requirement. In this case, the requirement is to simplify the demo and use zookeeper as the registry center. This is done to potentially improve the performance, reliability, and scalability of the application.

The commit message 'Auto configure micrometer cache metrics' indicates that the commit is adding support for cache metrics in the Micrometer library. This change improves the code by enabling the instrumentation of all available caches, which will provide metrics for cache usage. This is beneficial for monitoring and optimizing the performance of the application.

The commit message 'Avoid blocking on a Mono indefinitely' directly mentions the defect it fixes, which is the issue of blocking on a Mono indefinitely. This change is made to improve the code by ensuring that the Mono completes within a specified duration, thus avoiding potential issues.

The commit message 'Polish 'Clarify edge case docs on ConditionalOnClass'' refers to improving the documentation to clarify an edge case scenario. This is done to address the issue of ambiguity in the previous documentation, making it easier for developers to understand the behavior of the ConditionalOnClass annotation.
The commit message refers to the use of a deprecated class in tests, which is an issue that needs to be addressed. The message also provides a link to the issue, which further elaborates the problem.

The commit message describes the issue of incorrect reporting when a negative outcome is added for a source, and any existing outcomes for inner classes of that source are not updated. This is a clear description of the problem and the motivation for the code change.

The commit message updates the reference documentation to include details of Amazon Elastic Beanstalk. This is done to describe the source of the requirements, which is the need of software development for requirements of users. Specifically, the documentation is updated to provide information about deploying a Spring Boot application on AWS Elastic Beanstalk, which is a requirement for users who want to deploy their applications on this platform.

The commit message refers to the issue of making the UserDetailsService effectively available, which is directly elaborating the motivation of the code change. The issue is described as the need to make the UserDetailsService available as it would be if we used AuthenticationManagerBuilder.inMemoryAuthentication() as a shared object in the HttpSecurity. The diff also supports this by adding a method to set the UserDetailsService field in the AuthenticationManagerBuilder.

The commit message refers to the issue of generating default values from Duration and Period .ZERO. This is done to address the shortcoming of the previous implementation, which did not include these default values. The code diff also supports this explanation, as it adds the default values for Duration.ZERO and Period.ZERO to the WELL_KNOWN_STATIC_FINALS map, and adds new assertions to test these values in the FieldValuesTest class.

The commit message refers to the issue of upgrading to a newer version of the Maven Enforcer Plugin. This is likely due to a known bug or issue in the current version that the new version addresses. Therefore, the commit is made to fix a specific issue, which falls under the 'Describe Issue' category.

The commit message refers to the removal of a multi config runApplication extension which was used to run a Spring Boot application with multiple primary sources. This change was made to close a pull request, which likely described an issue or a problem with the existing implementation. Therefore, the most suitable category for this commit message is 'Describe Issue'.

The commit message refers to a change in Spring Security 5.0.1, which is an external dependency. This change requires an alignment of the default scopes for Google in the codebase to match the new version. Therefore, the category 'Illustrate Requirement' is the most suitable.

The commit message describes the need for the change, which is to add an option to exclude devtools from the fat jar. This is a requirement to support certain use cases where the other Boot features are needed but not this one.

The commit message 'Align with Spring Framework 5's new Commons Logging adapter' indicates that the change is being made to align with a new requirement or standard set by Spring Framework 5. This is a clear illustration of a source of requirements.

The commit message directly elaborates the motivation of the code change by mentioning the issue of an undefined FILE appender in the basic log4j configuration. This issue is likely causing errors or unexpected behavior, so the change is necessary to fix it.

The commit message refers to an issue that is being addressed, which is a common reason for code changes. The issue is mentioned directly in the message and a link is provided. This falls under the 'Describe Issue' category.

The commit message directly mentions the improvements it makes to the code, which is adding a new method to the Call interface that returns the call's timeout. This change is made to address the issue of signaling the end of the call, which occurs after the last byte is consumed of the last follow up request, or when the call fails. The commit also adds tests to ensure the new functionality works as expected.

The commit message refers to the addition of Android tests, which is likely due to the need to improve the software development process. The code changes include adding tests for additional OkHttp libraries and configuring the build to include these tests when not running in an IDE. This is likely to ensure that the tests are run as part of the continuous integration process, improving the reliability and maintainability of the software.
